review.title: Finding Modes by Probabilistic Hypergraphs Shifting
review.abstract: In this paper, we develop a novel paradigm, namely hypergraph shift, to find robust graph modes by probabilistic voting strategy, which are semantically sound besides the self-cohesiveness requirement in forming graph modes. Unlike the existing techniques to seek graph modes by shifting vertices based on pair-wise edges (i.e, an edge with $2$ ends), our paradigm is based on shifting high-order edges (hyperedges) to deliver graph modes. Specifically, we convert the problem of seeking graph modes as the problem of seeking maximizers of a novel objective function with the aim to generate good graph modes based on sifting edges in hypergraphs. As a result, the generated graph modes based on dense subhypergraphs may more accurately capture the object semantics besides the self-cohesiveness requirement. We also formally prove that our technique is always convergent. Extensive empirical studies on synthetic and real world data sets are conducted on clustering and graph matching. They demonstrate that our techniques significantly outperform the existing techniques.
histories: Fixing some minor issues in PAKDD 2014

sections.heading: 2 Probabilistic Hypergraph Notations
sections.text: Unlike a simple graph, each edge of the hypergraph (known as the hyperedge) can connect more than two corners. Formally, we call a weighted hypergraph G = (V, E, W), with a vertex V = (v1, v2,..., v | V |}, hyperedge E = (e1, e2,..), and W = (e1), w (e2), · ·, w (e | E |)}}, where w (ei) is the weight of egg. The relationship between the hyperedge and corners is defined by the incidence matrix H, R | × | E |. Instead of assigning a hyperedge ej to a vertex vi with a binary decision, we probably put the values [5, 8] between the hyperedge and corners e. sections.heading: 3 Modes of Hypergraph
sections.text: We consider the mode of a hypergraph as a dense subhypergraph consisting of hyperedges with high self-compactness (TME = TME = 3). We first define the hypergraph density and then formulate the modes of a hypergraph leading to our hypergraph displacement algorithm in Section 4.Hypergraph Density. We describe the hypergraph G with n hyperedges by probability coordinate manner in which the hyperedge G is represented with n hyperedge mode, and p = {p1, p2,., pn}. Specifically, pi shows the probability of the probability clusters of G. Then the affinity value between each pair-wise x and y-wise x is defined.

sections.heading: 4 Hypergraph Shift Algorithm
sections.text: Normally the hypergraph can be very large, a natural question is how to perform modes that search on a large hypergraph? To answer this question, we perform mode searches on a subhypergraph and determine whether it is the mode of the hypergraph. If not, we switch to a new subhypergraph by extending the adjacent hyperedges of the current mode to perform mode searches. First, we examine the circumstances that determine whether the mode of a subhypergraph is the mode of that hypergraph. Suppose p is the mode of the subhypergraph S that contains m = | θ S | hyperedges, then we expand the m-dimensional p.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental Evaluations
sections.text: In this section, we conduct extensive experiments to evaluate the performance of hypergraph shift. In each experiment, specific experimental framework conditions are elaborated.Competitory. We compare our algorithm with some closely related methods presented as follows. For cluster evaluation, we consider the following competitors: - The method proposed by Liu et al. in [13] designate Liu et al. in the following. - The approach presented by Bulo et al. in [2] designate Bulo et al. in the following. - Efficient hypergraph clustering [12] (EHC) aims to handle the higher order relationships between data points and perform cluster searches by iteratively updating cluster affiliation for all nodes in parallel and converge relatively quickly. For graph matching, we compare our method with the state of the art below: - Graph Shift (GS). - Two Hypergraph Matching Methods (TM) [6] and (PM) [31].

sections.heading: 5.1 Clustering Analysis
sections.text: To evaluate cluster performance, we compare HS against Liu et al., Bulo et al., and EHC over the dataset of five crescents, as shown in Fig.4.We performed extensive tests, including cluster accuracy and drunkenness to five crescents, the gradually decreasing sampling density of 1200 ptsto 100 pts. We used the standard cluster method to normalize mutual information (NMI).NMI accuracy is calculated for each method in Fig.5 (a), in terms of decreasing sampling points and increasing outliers. It shows that hypergraph shifts even in sparser data, while EHC is rapidly degenerated by 600 pts.

sections.heading: 5.2 Graph Matching
sections.text: In this part we will present some experiments on graph matching problems. We will show that this graph matching problem is identical to the search for a graph with a certain amount of noise and outliers. Following the experimental setup of [14], the equivalence of the graph matching problem to the search for the mode can be described as follows. Suppose there are two sets of characteristic points, P and Q, from two images. For each point p-P we can find similar points q-Q, based on local characteristics. Each pair of (p, q) is a possible match and all of these pairs form the correspondence set C = (p, q) | p-P, q-Q}. Then a graph G is constructed on the basis of C with each vertex of G connecting a pair in C. Edge e (vi, vj) vi and vj reflecting the relationship between correspondence ci and cj.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a novel hypergraph shift algorithm that aims to find robust graph modes through probabilistic tuning strategies that are semantically solid in addition to self-cohesion. Experimental studies show that our paradigm outperforms modern cluster and matching approaches observed from both synthetic and real data sets. Future work would like to include multi-view features [26], [21], [23], [25], [27], [20], [24], [29] or high-level deep representations [22] for improvement.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, we develop a novel paradigm, namely hypergraph shift, to find robust graph modes by probabilistic voting strategy, which are semantically sound besides the self-cohesiveness requirement in forming graph modes. Unlike the existing techniques to seek graph modes by shifting vertices based on pair-wise edges (i.e, an edge with 2 ends), our paradigm is based on shifting high-order edges (hyperedges) to deliver graph modes. Specifically, we convert the problem of seeking graph modes as the problem of seeking maximizers of a novel objective function with the aim to generate good graph modes based on sifting edges in hypergraphs. As a result, the generated graph modes based on dense subhypergraphs may more accurately capture the object semantics besides the self-cohesiveness requirement. We also formally prove that our technique is always convergent. Extensive empirical studies on synthetic and real world data sets are conducted on clustering and graph matching. They demonstrate that our techniques significantly outperform the existing techniques.
